resources:
Freiburg Guide Details
AIzaSyDFJ0OXkYbA9fxdkrRA98S-476i42rekuE
History Jewish History Plaques Translations Excursions
Ludwigshöhe "Ludwigshöhe on the Schlossberg (castle mountain). 

Inscription:
"Ludwigshöhe. The duke of Zähringen, builder and founder of Freiburg in the year MCXX. Eternally grateful to the high descendant, our Ludwig great duke of Baden. 
Faithfully admired by the citizens of this oldest, first city of Zähringen.To joyously remember the VII. jubilee of the foundation. Lovingly dedicated on Ludwig Day Aug. MDCCCXX. solemnly inaugurated."" 47.993708 7.858219
Old City Wall Pavement inscription, that indicates the course ofthe city wall south west of the Augustiner museum.

inscription:
"Old city wall until ca. 1825" 47.9937 7.852275
Historic Merchants Hall The Historic Merchants Hall in Freiburg dates to 1520-21. The front facade is decorated with statues and coats of arms that were sculpted between 1520 and 1531 by Sixt von Staufen. The sculpted figures under baldachins show Emperor Maximilian I, King Philipp the Beautiful of Castile, Emperor Charles V and Emperor Ferdinand I - all Hapsburgs. 47.994953 7.852890
Gerichtslaube The Gerichtslaube where in 1498 the Reichstag was held 

A small gem from Freiburg’s past is located in the rear courtyard of the Old Town Hall, accessible from the Turmstrasse. It is the Gerichtslaube (court house), which was used for municipal matters at the beginning of Freiburg’s development. Between 1280 and 1300 the free-standing gabled house was built and originally used as a courtroom and a place where leading Freiburg citizens and aristocrats gathered. There was even a small jail in the cellar vaults. 47.996076 7.849318
Plaques on Martins Gate Plaques on Martin's Gate about its origins and the burning of witches

Inscription (left):
Martin's Gate
Initially Norsinger Gate. Oldest preserved fortified tower and gate from the medieval castle (beginning of 13th century). Restructured by C. Schäfer from 1901–03. Fully renovated in 1998.

(right): 
Burning of witches
Margaretha Mößmerin 
Catharina Stadellmentin
Anna Wolffartin 
beheaded and burned on 24th March 1599.

The City of Freiburg in Breisgau honour their memory at this location as well as all women, who fell victim to the witch persecutions. The suffering of these and all innocently tortured people is a living reprimand for tolerance and humanity.
 47.993725 7.848975
Breisach Town Gate One of the few remaining remnants of the fortification of Freiburg by Vauban. The former entry to the Breisach gate is now the entrance for a restaurant.
 47.992242 7.847719
Loretto Chapel "Cannon ball, that would have hit Louis XV on his observation post during his siege of Freiburg in 1744, stuck in the wall of Loretto's Chapel.
" 47.981375 7.838544
Martin's Gate The plate above the archway commemorates until today the battle between the Freiburg militia, that was founded in 1793, and the revultionary troops from France. 

The inscription:
"Monument to the volunteers of Freiburg under the major and city councilor Caluri and all the comrades-in-arms of Austria Breisgau, who honored themselves by their loyalty and bravery on 7th July 1796, for emperor and fatherland. Dedicated by their general baron von Duminique." 47.993775 7.849031
Tambur Graffiti at the Munster Graffiti by a German speaking drummer (tambur not tambour) of the Napoleanic Army 1810 on the outer wall of the munster choir.

Inscription: 
"Tambur Hagenbuch 1810" 47.995489 7.852983
Square of the Last Barricade Square of the last barricade during the 1848 Revolution near the Schwabentor. 47.9929 7.854033
Sternwald Memorial Memorial stone near Günterstal commemorating the freedom fighters who were killed on April 23, 1884 by government forces

Inscription:
"In memory of the fighters for freedom and democracy who fell in the fight against government forces on Easter Sunday, 1848." 47.970931 7.852028
Mausoleum for Maximilian Dortus The Mausoleum of Maximilian Dortus, German revolutionary of 1848-49 shot by government troops at the very place in the Wiehre cemetry. 47.985811 7.857147
Memorial for fallen Soldier (1848) Memorial stone erected in the od cemetry for the soldiers who died during the siege of Freiburg in 1848. The grand duke ordered the stone, which was donated by the comrades of the fallen, to be turned so that the inscription could not be read from the road.

Inscription:
"In memory of those fallen at the assault on Freiburg on 24th April 1848, by their comrades-in-arms." 48.000625 7.857602
Marks of the WW I Bomb Attack Marks found on College Building I of the Freiubrg university, caused by the British bomb attack from 14th April 1917. 47.993697 7.846094
Where The Imperial Eagle once soared. Place at the wall of the university building where the eagle of the Third Reich once hung. 47.993806 7.845594
Gurs Memorial Sign Post Memorial remembering the deportation of the Jews to the concentration camp in Gurs (South France) in the form of a sign post. 47.995228 7.846164
Wagner Bürckel Memorial Memorial at the place of the old synagogue in Freiburg for the so called Wagner-Bürckel campaign, where Jews from Baden and Palatinate regions were deported. 

The inscription:
"On the 22nd October 1940, in only a few hours 6,504 jewish men, women and children from Baden and Palatinate were brought to central concentration camps and from there deported to camp Gurs in southern france. The oldest was 97 years old. Among them were about 300 jewish fellow citizens from Freiburg.

Those who didn’t die because of hunger and diseases, were deported mainly to the eastern extermination camps Auschwitz and Maidanék from August 1942 on. Over 5,200 of those deported to Gurs died as victims of violence.

Too many have then looked away, too few have resisted. This must not and will not be repeated. 47.995228 7.846164
"Stumbling Stones" Stumbling Stones are memorial plaques found all across Freiburg in memory of each Jew who lived at that address. They include their names, birth, deportation and/or death date. This is the biggest cluster of six stumbling stones found at Eisenbahnstraße 66 commemorating members of the families Abraham and Grumbacher. 47.997319 7.843346
Memorial on the "Blaue Brücke" Memmorial remembering the Jewish citizens from Freiburg and surroundings, who were deported to Gurs, France, on 22/10/1940.

The inscription: 
"22/10/1940 over 450 Jews from Freiburg and the area were deported on the order of the National Socialist regional adminsitrator from the warehouse of the station of the time to the South French camp Gurs.
Many of them already died in Gurs due to hunger and illnesses, most were murdered in the extermination camp Auschwitz.

City of Freiburg, October 2003" 47.996014 7.840006
Memorial at the Hebel School Memorial marker on the Hebel School in Freiburg, Germany. Jews from southern Germany were assembled in the schoolyard on October 22, 1940, immediately prior to walking to the nearby train station and then being transported to the concentration camp at Gurs, France.

The inscription:

"22/10/1940 here in the Hebel school yard many hundreds of Jews from South Germany were taken into custody and transported to Gurs for inihalation. 

In memory and to always remember.

Never again Fashism
Never again National Socialism
Never again xenophobia. 47.997503 7.835736
"Käthe-Vordetreide-Weg" road sign " Riesefeld is a new suburb of Freiburg, that took the opportunity of creating new street names to commemorate a Jewish citizen from WW II. 

The inscription:
"K. Vortriede 1891–1964, jorunalist in Freiburg, Jew and Social Democrate was forced to emigrate in 1939. Author of letters critical of the time."" 47.998016 7.785265
Memorial for the destroyed synagogue In front of the college building II of the Freiburg university is this memorial commemorating the old synagogue that stood here, that was destroyed during WW II.

 The inscription:
 "Here stood the synagogue of the Israeli community of Freiburg. Built in 1870 it was destroyed 10th November, 1938, under a reign of violence and injustice." 47.994504 7.846062
Plaque on exterior wall of New Synagogue Memorial for the deportation of the Jews in Freiburg on 22 October 1940, mounted on the exterior wall of Freiburg's new synagogue by the city of Freiburg in 1990.

The inscription:
"Earth, do not cover my blood and may my cry never be laid to rest. Job 16,18

On 22nd October, 1940 the Jewish citizens of city Freiburg were deportet to Gurs in Sotuh France under the NS-Diktatur regime. The city remembers in shame and grief. Freiburg, 22nd October 1990." 47.996394 7.853619
Plaque at entrance of the New Synagogue Plaque at the entrance to Freiburg's new synagogue, dedicated on November 5, 1987.

Inscription:
"The Freiburg Synagogue, after pillage and destruction during the NS-era, was re-edified and dedicated on November 5th, 1987.

my house will be called a house of prayer for all nations. Is 56,7" 47.996394 7.853619
Schelenz Memorial Walter Schelenz, Mahnmal für die Opfer des Nationalsozialismus, 1975, – Rotteckring, Platz der Alten Synagoge. 47.996078 7.846633
Memorial of the Jewish Deportation at the Anna Square Memorial for the Jewish deportation to Gurs at the Anna square in Freiburg

Inscription:
Citizens from the Baden, Palatinate and Saar Region of Jewish beliefs or those who were declared Jewish by the inhuman race ideology were deported under the terror regime of National Socialism.

The abduction of the women, men and children from the Wiehre suburb concerned started in this place infront of all eyes, taking them to the South French concentration camp Gurs.

Most died there from the inhuman camp conditions or were murdered later." 47.985164 7.845881
Memorial by Herder Edition Infront of the college building II of the Freiburg University is the memorial donated by the Herder Edition. 

The two lying stone slabs have the inscription:
"In gratitude for the preservation of the city and munster on 27th November, 1944 and in memory of the synagogue." 47.994575 7.846214
Momuent at the Jewish Cemetry Denkmal für die jüdischen Opfer der Gewaltherrschaft von 1933 - 1945.

Inschriftentafel:
"Den jüdischen Opfern der Gewaltherrschaft 1933 – 1945" 48.012443 7.828644
Memorial Plaques at Lessing School Memorial at the site of the compulsory school for Jewish children from Freiburg and the surrounding region that operated from October 21, 1936, until the Reichskristallnacht on November 10, 1938.

first plaque:
"In memory and as warning 
Compulsory school for Jewish children

Jewish children from Freiburg and the surrounding region were taught here, because they were not allowed to attend general schools due to the racist laws. The students, their family and teachers were up against the national socialistic persecution and extermination politics. Thanks to brae people form the resistance many of these children could survive, but not their relatives.
The rescuers are an example of tolerance and civil courage to us. We mourn with the rescued for the murdered. 
✡
From 21st October, 1936 to the Reichsprogromnacht on 10th November 1938 the compulsory school was accommodated in this building. From March 1939 until the deportations to Gurs in South West Fance on 22nd October 1940 lessons were held in the Jewish community house next to the synagogue at the Werthmann Square.
October 2004"

second plaque:
"Over 60 Jewish students kam

from Breisach Raplh Eisemann, Bianca Gelsmar,Werner Geisamer, Günther Levy, Gretel Levy, Ruth Levy, Rosi Uffenheimer, Alex Wurmser, Alfred Weil, from Eichstetten Wittrude Hene, Ilse Weil, from Emmendingen Alfred Geismar, Else Geismar, Lore Grünebaum, Hugo Günzburger, Lisbeth Günzburger, Susi Günzburger, Herta Weil, Margot Weil, from Freiburg Heinrich Alpern, Alice Bloch, Rudolf Bloch, Walter Bloch, Herbert Burger, Marlene Goldstein, Gertrude Günzburger, Nelly Heilbrunner, Ilse Judas, Renate Kaufmann, Walter Kaufmann, Ruth Mayer, Max Plaut, Hanna Reichmann, Hede Reutlinger, Rita Rosenberger, Esther Schärf, Manfred Schärf, Leo Wertheimer, from Friesenheim Richard Levi, from Haslach Eugen Moses, Helmut Moses,"

third plaque:
"from Ihringen Anneliese Judas, Karl Judas, Gretel Judas, Ingeborg Judas, Kurt Judas, Kurt Lion, from Kenzingen Alice Dreifuß, from Kippenheim Heinz Maier, Kurt Maier, Flora Wertheimer, from Müllheim Rolf Zivi, Wolfgang Zivi, from Offenburg Esther Cohn, Eva Cohn, Myriam Cohn, Susi Greilsheimer, Renate Haberer, Hedwig Hammel, Ingeborg Hammel, Rudolf Hammer, Kurt Hammel, Hannelore Kahn, Margot Kramer, Selma Maier, from Sohmieheim Egon Bloch, Lore Bloch, Margot Dreyfuss, from Villingen Lotte Schwab, … 

The teachers
Dr. Alice Weil-Mendel, Alfred Kaufmann, Adolf Reutlinger, Klara Maier, Dr. Ilse Hamburger, Professor Maier and Herr Strauß.
July 2006" 47.989753 7.847206
Plaque for Otto Lenel Plaque for Otto Lenel in front of his former house in Freiburg im Breisgau, Holbeinstraße 5

Inschrift:
"Professor of Roman rights Otto Lenel 1849–1935 lived in this house from 1909 onwards." 47.982048 7.845118
Convent of Preacher Information plaque saying:
"Here stood the Convent for Preachers from the middle of the 13th century until its abolition in 1794, a glowing place for medieval research and religion. Even Albertus Magnus, one of the leading spirits of the Western World taught ecclesial and secular earls within these walls. 1492 emperor Maximilian was received a friendly reception. In the frigthful night of 27th November, 1944 the remains of the convents sank to rubble." 47.997603 7.848494
Plaque at Old City Hall Plaque offering details about the new and old town hall as well as the court house:

"New Town Hall
the new town hall, located between Rathausgasse and Turmstraße was created in its current form by converting the old town houses "Zum Phönix"(the Phoenix) and "Zum Rechen" (the Rake). It was the main college building of the university between 1578 and 1774. The baroque furnished auditorium on the first floor and the original entry gate of the university, which is now found to the rear of the courtyard, where builtduring this period and survive to this day.
The building was home to various university institutes during the 19th century, e.g. anatomy. After the comprehensive extensions from 1896 to 1901 – a council hall corridor was added above the entry and the little bell tower – the city administration moved into the building. An extenvie renovation was completed in 2000/2001 thanks to donations from the township and economy.

Old Town Hall
The Northerly situationed old town hall is linked to the new town hall by a bridge. The Freiburg town clerk worked here as early as the 13th century. The current house was built between 1556 and 1561. It was linked to two other town houses at a later date. All that remains from the initial construction is the crypt of the Klarissa Covenant founded in 1272.
The building was burnt to the ground during the air raids on Freiburg in 1944. As part of the reconstruction from 1952 to 1958 trhee wings were added. It was thoroughly renovated in 2000/2001 thanks to donations by the township and economy.

The Court House 
tThe large and small court room have been in this house since 1328, which is now situated in the courtyard of the old town hall. Since 1480 the municipal court also meet here. In 1497/98 the Reichstag, appointed by emperor Maximilan I., convened here. Since 1546 there have been many changes to this building. In 1863 they even added a third floor.
During the air raids in November 1944 the court house was practically destroyed, leaving little more than its foundation walls. Only the stone-arched and iron doors shielded the archive wing and its complete equipment from 1553 leaving it mostly intact. The reconstructed building, partially financed by donations, can be used for receptions and sessons since 1979." 47.996102 7.849038
Basler Hof Commemorative plaque in the Basler Hof referring to Gestapo activities
 
 Inscription:
 "In Memory
 The Basler Hof was the seat of the Secret State Police (Gestapo).
 Here people were summoned, interrogated, humiliated and tortured.
 We remember the victims of the national socialist terror regime and those citizens, who suffered in this house." 47.996481 7.851881
Three Trees for the Germany Unity Plaque in DietenbackPark, Freiburg:
"A growing memorial for the German Unity.
This green living memorial represents 25 years reunion. Germany is growing together, just like these trees.
The pine tree symbolises the East.
The beech tree symbolises the West.
The oak tree symbolises the unification of Germany.
An initiate by Werner Erhard
Under the patronage of the Federal Chancellor Dr. Angela Merkel
Supported by the protective assosciation German Forest 48.000212 7.800328
Eugen Martin Memorial Plaque in Seepark Freiburg
"Eugen Martin installation
Eugen Martin (1925–2010), honorary citizen of Freiburg, gave the rose garten in Seepark new life. 
The generous donation by the rose enthusiast Eugen Martin enabled the planting of over 150 rose bushes in the rose garden created for the hauticultural show in 1986.
The rose garden was dedicated to its sponsor on 4th June 2011." 48.006872 7.824419
Memorial plaque for Constantin Fehrenbach at Schwarzwaldstraße 1 in Freiburg

"this house was built by and residence of
Constantin Fehrenbach 1852–1926
Reich Chancellor of the Weimar Republic 1920–1921" 47.990624 7.854865
Fehsenfeld's Edition Wallstraße 10, Freiburg: plaque: the edition of Friedrich Ernst Fehsenfeld (1853–1933) was seated here from 1890–1895, which published the ‘Freiburg Edition’ of the works by Karl May. 47.992006 7.851907
Memorial Plaque for Dr. Hoffmann and his Wife "Here lies the best and most faithful of all mothers Johanne Frederick Hoffmann née Bleymüller.
* 19th August 1780
† 24th March 1860

Here lies an old man, who always followed his own research and dreams building on justice instead blindly trusting human law. Those who knew him bear witness to this. May the almighty judge offer us mercy and clarity.
Christian august Hoffmann, dr. med.
* 27th August, 1790. † 6th December 1868." 47.992637 7.86182
Schlossberg: A Hint of History A Hint of History
Freiburg and the Schlossberg were always of particular interest due to their situation. The Schlossberg bears its name with reason, as the Zähringer already erected their castle called “Burghaldenschloss” here in the 11th century.
The securities around the Burghaldenschlosswere tightened during the 30-year war. The canon square stems from this era. Freiburg was at the center of the conflict between Austria and France after 1648. The city was conquered in 1677 and incorporated together with this castle in a mighty fortress, designed by the architect Vauban by order of the French king Ludwig XIV. The fortification and castle were destroyed in 1744. The points of the wooden bars on the play ground commemorate the lances and spears and with them the war times, when soldiers used to stand guard on the fortress walls. 47.993273 7.856948
Schlossberg: Historic Walk Display 3 Schlossberg of Freiburg Fortress
Historic walk
 Display number You are here o
The upper castle
(Fort Saint Pierre)
The strung out upper castle was the main part of the fortification and was built by engineers starting in 1679 following plans by Sébastien de Vauban. It creates a constructional unit with the storage (Fort Carré oder Fort de l’Etoile), which enabled secure access from the lower castle. The actual upper castle incorporates storage and barracks. 

Isometrics of the upper castle “Fort de St. Pierre”. The main archway was found here 0: Austrian war archives Vienna. 

The Peterkirche (church) stood in the center of the courtyard. On the North the upper castle was shielded by a hornworm, to the North West by a bigger construction.
The path coming from the present Burghaldenring secured the upstream route (Redoute du Chemie), which can still be traced easily in the terrain today.

Ground plan of the upper castle with Salzbüchsle 0 and the upstream buildings “Plan et situation du Salspuchsle” found in: Austria. war archive Vienna. 

The castle access is gained via a architecturally complex created main gateway (porte Prinzipale)

Ground plan and aspect of the main gateway of the upper castle “Plan et Elevation dune porte du Fort St. Pierre” l’Inspection du Geier Vincennes

 with upstream, triangular place of arms (place d’armes), which has also left its mark in the terrain (located display plaque). A deconstructible bridge went from the place of arms over the trench to the gateway, which lead through the inner wall. A covered path went along the outside of the trench (Chemie couvert), which was lowered towards the sloped exterior (glacis) and was secured by stockades. The process of the stockades can be traced following the concretee bollards.

We offer our gratitude to Sparkasse Freiburg-Northern Breisgau for supporting the Freiburg Schlosserg e.V. board of trustees. We also offer our gratitude to Bernhard Sänger GmbH, construction company and company Dr. Lauck, surface technology for the manufacturing of these information boards. 47.996476 7.865878
Schlossberg: Historic Walk Display 4 Fortress: Schlossberg of Freiburg
The Schlossberg as part of city history
From time immemorial the Dream valley of the Freiburg area created an important access point to the high Black Forest area. Thus the Schlossberg was a strategically important place to command the area from. It was seized in 1091 bei the dukes of Zähringen as their main castle and at its feet they founded the city of Freiburg. Following the 30-year war the by now Habsburgian city and the Schlossberg were sieged by French troops in 1677 and expanded to a modern fortress following the plans by the renown architect Vauban. Freiburg rejoined the Reich in 1697, but was reconquered in 1713 and 1744 by the French, who before finally leaving in 1745 completed the fortification. This brought a distressing era of wars to a close, that cost 30,000 soldiers from Freiburg their lives. A new light forest park was created, pervaded by walkways, on the ruins of the Schlossberg fortress by the end of the 19th century. After WW II the history was sinking more and more into oblivion.
The Freiburg Schlossberg board of trustees, founded in 1997, set itself the target, to make the prominent meaning of the Schlossberg for Freiburg visible again. From the Schlossberg tower you can enjoy a wonderful view of the city and its history, which was erected by the board of trustees in 2002. On you way there you will encounter further information boards.

The sandstone plaque adjacent to this board was erected on the canon square at the start of the 19th century. The single sections of the Schlossberg fortress listed on the plaque are in part misleading. They are based on confusions and do not correspond with the terminology used by Vauban in his build of the construction. These can be found on the indications offered by the aluminium plaques mounted on the old construction. 47.993507 7.857405
Schlossberg: Historic Walk Display 10 Schlossberg of Freiburg Fortress
Historic walk 
Display number 0 You are here o
Communication between castles via the Salzbüchsle
The castle fortification based on the plans of the castle building commissioner Vauban comprised of the upper castle (Fort St. Pierre und Fort Carré) on the highest elevation, the lower castle (Ancien Château) and Salzbüchsle (Fort de L’Aigle) situated between the two. The upper castle contained the main warehouse of the overall structure.

Plan view of the fortification with its communication. Extract from “Les forts de la Montagne de Fribourg”, ca. 1685.
Bibliothque de l’inspection du Genie Vincennnes [sic!].”

Because of this they needed to install an efficient transport link between the three parts of the fortification. This link (la Communication) allowing two-way traffic was installed on the Schlossberg ridge around 1680. A small reroute was attached to the link south of the Salzbüchsle. 

Traverse section „Profil d la grande Communication dans l’Etat ou elle est présentement“. Circa 1715, city archive of Freiburg.

To enable communication during a siege, the Link was integrated into the castle and furnished by stockades on both sides. The wall trenches of this stockade paths could be excavated for the most part in good condition. In contrast the lower link was mostly destroyed in 1745. Comte de la Venerie called on the imperial manager of the fortification to reinforce the defenders of the construction after the siege in by the French army in 1713. The location of this display x marks the remnants of the second ring wall around the Salzbüchsle from 1728. 

Second surrounding wall of the Salzbüchsle. „Plan de … Salzbüchslein comme als doit être renforcé” Mâchoire Auguste Comte de la Venerie 1723. Austrian war archive Vienna. 

Traverse section. „Profil du Saltzbüschlein et de des nouveaux ouvrages“, Melchior Auguste Comte de la Venerie 1723/28. Austrian war archive Vienna. 

Special thanks to Sparkasse Freiburg Northern Breisgau for their support.
 47.995364 7.863346
Strasbourg Strasbourg is the capital of Elsass, France. 48.579444 7.738389
Colmar Colmar is the third-largest commune of the Alsace region in north-eastern France. 48.0766 7.358214
Europa Park Europa-Park in Rust (Germany) is Germany's biggest theme park. 48.267111 7.719194
Staufen Staufen lies in Breisgau Hochschwarzwald (Black Forest), Baden_Württemberg. The city houses ca. 7800 citizens and is first mentioned in documents from the 7th century. With the castle ruin as its backdrop the historic city center comes to its full bloom. The Faust-legend supports its atmosphere, placing the meeting between Faust and the devil in a hotel right in the center of the city. 47.886379 7.731944
Schauinsland As the name hints at, the Schauinsland (literally: look into the land) offers a beautiful vista over the Black Forest and Breisgaul 47.9022433 7.904642
Titisee Titisee is a small lake and town in the Black Forest (Schwarzwald) in Baden-Württemberg. 47.899143 8.153425
Schluchsee The Lake of Schluch is a reservoir near St. Balsien in Breisgau-Hoschschwarzwald (Black Forest), Baden-Württemberg. It lies to the South East of the Lake of Titi and is the largest lake of the Balck Forest. 47.842211 8.112609
Basel "Basel is a city in northwestern Switzerland on the river Rhine. Basel is Switzerland's third-most-populous city (after Zürich and Geneva) with about 175,000 inhabitants.

Located where the Swiss, French and German borders meet, Basel also has suburbs in France and Germany. The cities agglomeration has ca. 830,000 inhabitants. 

The city encorporates GrossBasel on the left (southwest) side of the Rhine and Kleinbasel (incorporating the old fishing village Kleinhüningen) on the right bank of the Rhine. The center of the old town lies in Grossbasel around the market square – where the town hall (built in 1504) stands – and the munster hill towering over the Pfalz-terrasse. The "Mittlere Brücke" connects the old city on both sides of the Rhine. The city center is freed from car traffic with public transport offered by tram. 

The city is known for its various internationally renowned museums, ranging from the Kunstmuseum, the first collection of art accessible to the public in Europe, to the Fondation Beyeler (located in Riehen), and its centuries long commitment to Humanism, offering a safe haven among others to Erasmus of Rotterdam, the Holbein family, and more recently also to Hermann Hesse and Karl Jaspers. Basel has been the seat of a Prince-Bishopric since the 11th century, and joined the Swiss Confederacy in 1501. " 47.559601 7.588576
